content.definition: An aneurysm of the celiac trunk or its major branches (hepatic, splenic, left gastric), representing approximately 4% of visceral artery aneurysms. Celiac artery aneurysms have significant rupture risk and require careful consideration of collateral circulation when planning intervention.

pathophysiology.true_aneurysm: All three layers involved, atherosclerotic degeneration

indications_for_treatment: All celiac aneurysms should be considered for repair (high rupture risk)

collateral_preservation: Must assess collateral adequacy before ligation
hepatic_ischemia_risk: If hepatic artery sacrificed, ensure collateral flow

learning_objectives: Know higher rupture risk of celiac aneurysms compared to other visceral
clinical_pearls: Celiac aneurysms have HIGHER rupture risk (10-20%) than splenic (3%)
All celiac aneurysms should be considered for repair
Post-stenotic aneurysm in MALS is common presentation
Must preserve hepatic perfusion (GDA collateral from SMA)
Male predominance (unlike splenic which affects women)
